items.title: Calculate the datetime before 12 months
items.body:
this is what I am using now:
 moment.now().add(years=-2, months=-12, days=-3).format('YYYY-M-D')

The reason is that the parameter is not considered as a negative number in the moment.date.update_month method.

items.title: CONDA Install?
items.body: Is there a conda install for this?

items.title: date returns datetime
items.body:
```
>>> moment.now().date                                                                                
datetime.datetime(2020, 3, 28, 1, 50, 18, 374926)
```

items.title: Is this library dead?
items.body: Seems pretty broken...no updates for a year.

items.title: moment.date("2 weeks from now") yields NoneType
items.body:
I was using one of the examples:
`moment.date("2 weeks from now")`

But it seems to not be working properly because I keep getting a NoneType

items.title: Offset doesn't change with timezone
items.body:
>>> now = moment.now()
>>> print(now)
2018-06-05T17:13:28-07.00
>>> print(now.timezone("US/Central"))
2018-06-05T18:04:28-07.00
>>> print(now.timezone("US/Mountain"))
2018-06-05T17:04:28-07.00
>>> print(now.timezone("US/Pacific"))
2018-06-05T16:04:28-07.00

items.title: can not get unix timestamp
items.body:
in nodejs moment , we can get unix timestamp by moment().valueOf() or moment().format('x').
but in this library , both of them are not supported

items.title: Is this project maintained?
items.body:
Hey,

I'd very much like this project to be fleshed out more to be on par with moment.js, but I don't want to make Pull Requests and stuff on a project that isn't being maintained.

I'm happy making PRs or, if you don't want to handle this anymore, I'm also happy with taking over the package.

items.title: Parsing a year creates a date in the 1st of July
items.body:
Is it a bug or undocumented feature? Not sure if I understand it. Thanks in advance.

```
In [1]: import moment

In [2]: moment.date('2000').date
Out[2]: datetime.datetime(2000, 7, 1, 0, 0)
```

items.title: Travis integration is broken
items.body: Hi @zachwill ! I noticed that the build badge in the readme doesn't render properly: And when you click on it, Travis says "The repository at zachwill/moment was not found." You should be able to re-add the repo to Travis on https://travis-ci.org/profile/.

items.title: type error when using add method
items.body:
When I use something like `moment.utcnow().add(years=3, months=2).format("YYYY-M-D h:m A")`
i get a type error that says `integer argument expected, got float`. How should I go about resolving this issue? I have tried a couple of things, but couldn't seem to get it to work as expected.

items.title: add weekday to get the next specified day of week
items.body:
In **date.py**, function **add**, adding condition 

```
        elif key == 'weekdays' or key == 'weekday':
            delta = (amount - self.weekday) % 7
            delta = 7 if not delta else delta
            self.add('days', delta)
```

`moment.now().add(weekday=7)` return the date of next sunday

regards

items.title: add months fails
items.body:
in date.py, on line 29 in function definition, replace `year = date.year + month / 12` with `year = date.year + int(month / 12)`

regards

items.title: moment.now().utc() fails
items.body:
I know we have utcnow(), but I was just trying some things in the commandline on python3.5:

``` python
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-10-fff227e9a2c4> in <module>()
----> 1 moment.now().utc()

/home/stu/.virtualenvs/ng/lib/python3.5/site-packages/moment/core.py in utc(self, *args)
     29     def utc(self, *args):
     30         """Create a moment from a UTC date."""
---> 31         date, formula = parse_date_and_formula(*args)
     32         self._date = pytz.timezone('UTC').localize(date)
     33         self._formula = formula

/home/stu/.virtualenvs/ng/lib/python3.5/site-packages/moment/parse.py in parse_date_and_formula(*args)
     13             # Python datetime needs the month and day, too.
     14             date = [date[0], 1, 1]
---> 15         date = datetime(*date)
     16     elif isinstance(date, str) or isinstance(date, unicode):
     17         if formula is None:

TypeError: Required argument 'year' (pos 1) not found

```

items.body:
Hi, 
if I try to parse the the following. I get an error that shouldnt appear.

ValueError: 'P' is a bad directive in format '%B %d, %Y [%Pt]'

Thanks for any help

items.title: toISOString format
items.body:
In momentjs, we have moment().toISOString();  What would be the correct way to use your library to get the same result?

Thanks!

items.title: Python 3 support
items.body:
Hi.

I've been trying to use Moment with Python 3.4 and got this:

```
In [1]: import moment

In [2]: moment.now().subtract(monthes=6)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-9407b0856ff3> in <module>()
----> 1 moment.now().subtract(monthes=6)

/usr/lib/python3.4/site-packages/moment/date.py in subtract(self, key, amount, **kwds)
     65         """Subtract time from the original moment."""
     66         if not key and not amount and len(kwds):
---> 67             for k, v in kwds.iteritems():
     68                 self.subtract(k, v)
     69         if key == 'years' or key == 'year':

AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'iteritems'
```

items.title: Creating Moment with default formatting doesn't work
items.body:
The function `parse_date_and_formula` seems to suggest I can use the default formula for new dates (`"%Y-%m-%d"`). However that leads to an error:

``` python
>>> moment.date("2014-01-01")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/svisser/.virtualenvs/test/lib/python2.7/site-packages/moment/core.py", line 109, in __repr__
    return "<Moment(%s)>" % (self._date.strftime(self._formula))
AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'strftime'
```

The difference is best seen when calling the parse function directly:

``` python
>>> from moment.parse import parse_date_and_formula
>>> parse_date_and_formula("2014-01-01")
('2014-01-01', '%Y-%m-%d')
>>> parse_date_and_formula("2014-01-01", "%Y-%m-%d")
(datetime.datetime(2014, 1, 1, 0, 0), '%Y-%m-%d')
```

items.title: Use ISO format for `repr` representation
items.body:
String provided by `repr` of date is misleading:

```
>>> import moment
>>> m = moment.date("11-12-2012", "M-D-YYYY")
>>> repr(m)
'<Moment(11-12-2012)>'
>>> m2 = moment.date("11-12-2012", "D-M-YYYY")
>>> repr(m2)
'<Moment(11-12-2012)>'
>>> m.date
datetime.datetime(2012, 11, 12, 0, 0)
>>> m2.date
datetime.datetime(2012, 12, 11, 0, 0)
```

As you see, while the dates are different, strings returned are equal:

```
>>> m == m2
False
>>> repr(m) == repr(m2)
True
```

This is against convention, that `repr` tries to represent the value as precisely as possible.

Proposal: print the value as ISO formatted string.

items.title: Add isoformat method
items.body:
Moment instances should have an isoformat method — similar to datetime.

```
import moment
moment.now().isoformat()
```

items.title: Should be able to add/subtract non-plural keywords
items.body:
The following behavior should add an hour to my date:

```
import moment
moment.utcnow().add(hour=1)
```

items.title: Get rid of date methods
items.body: Really should just settle on the property rather than including all 3 in the package. Could include a deprecation warning and remove them from the documentation.

items.title: Feature request: duration representation, natural language parsing, recurring events
items.body:
Feature wise, how does this compare to the Ruby libraries https://github.com/mojombo/chronic and https://github.com/hpoydar/chronic_duration ? I'm not seeing any natural language parsing, or representations of duration. How stable is the API? If it is pretty stable I might make a weekend project out of implementing some of this. It sounds like fun.

Also, would it be possible to represent recurring events using generators? I can think of use cases where that might be useful.

If I get around to adding these things, would it be better to implement them within moment, or in a new module dependent on moment?

Thanks for the great library!

items.title: Unpythonic parts of API
items.body:
I think the pythonic way of writing the following:

``` python
m.add('days', 2).subtract('weeks', 3)
```

should be:

``` python
m.add(days=2).subtract(weeks=3)
```

Which allows for:

``` python
m.add(days=3, weeks=1)
```

Also, why not make a `Moment` a subclass fo `datetime`? Then you don't need to have `.done()`.

PS. I actually wanted to make a datetime library with same name but with `Moment` class, which would be a subclass of `datetime` (for backwards compatibility), but with better API. Sounds like very similar goal to yours? :-)

I thought of API based around [ISO 8601](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601) time format. Something like:

``` python
from moment import Moment

m = Moment('2012-12-31T23:59+0100')

assert str(m) == '2012-12-31T23:59+0100'
assert repr(m) == "Moment('2012-12-31T23:59+0100')"

assert m.subtract(days=1, hours=3) == Moment('2012-12-30T20:59+0100')
assert m.replace(day=15, hour=1) == Moment('2012-12-15T01:59+0100')

assert m.day == 15
assert m.days == 234234234234.2332  # number of days since year 1

assert m.hour == 1
assert m.hours == 2342423423423423423.23423  # number of hours since year 1

m2 = Moment('31/12/1999', format='DD/MM/YYYY')
assert m2 == Moment('1999-12-31')
assert m2.format('YYYY-mississippi-MM-mississippi-DD') == '1999-mississippi-12-mississippi-31'
```

Is it different enough from your vision that I need to start a different library, or can we work on it together?
